column2: Sunday morning visit to splendid campus

In Romanesque Revival form it was also inspired by an Italian Basilica. It is named in honour of the university librarian with a tenure of 17 years from 1944.Marvellous modern sculptures are to be admired in the Franklin D. Murphy Sculpture Garden. An outstanding collection. A number of interesting temporary exhibitions were underway at the Fowler Museum.

As you traverse the streets and pathways of Westwood, you start to discover a beautiful campus setting with all the trappings of a "Southern California" environment. Student pedestrian and cycling traffic reflect the academic dedication that is required for success on this campus. The diversions of play spaces, grassy quadrants, party establishments and suburban style entertainment options color the campus with a unique blend of academia, suburbia, and college frivolity. column2: Self-Guide Tour of UCLA and Westwood
column3: We checked into the Royal Palace Westwood on a Thursday evening, after a Lyft ride from Disneyland, and we spent Friday walking around the UCLA Campus and Westwood. We checked out on Saturday morning and took a short ride to LAX via Lyft. The hotel was a great value and included a modest buffet breakfast; the WiFi cut out a few times so I used my own hotspot. Our room was light and airy thanks to a sliding glass door onto a balcony overlooking a quiet side-street. The room was quiet with the door shut and on Friday morning we slept late, the day before at Disney having been a long one. At UCLA, we were surprised and disappointed to find the Botanical Gardens closed for maintenance work. As we made our way to the Sculpture Garden, we stopped in at the Charles Young Research Library and had a coffee. Back out in the Sculpture Garden we asked a kindly gentleman the way to the Fowler Museum and, very generous with his time, he took us to it. It developed that he was a UCLA grad and he worked in Admissions there. His kindliness made a huge impression of UCLA on us. The Fowler is worth a long visit; ours was a bit too short as we needed to get to the Ackerman Union for lunch at Wolfgang Puck Express. The rest of the day was spent in Westwood, including window shopping, and some trying a few things on and visiting the Hammer Museum. For the evening, the Geffen Playhouse was sold out, the Fox theater was showing a movie we had already seen, but we managed to get the last 3 seats at the iPic for a new film, and it was well worth it and a unique experience. Afterward we walked around looking at our options for dinner, which were several, and settled on the Napa Valley Grille. The fare was great. The bartender mixed up some drinks and they ended up scratching them from the tab, without a peep from us. This was a fun day. On our next visit we will aim to schedule an organized tour as there is clearly a lot more to see and do here, including the libraries, student facilities, and architecture of the original campus buildings.

column2: One of LA's Good Walking Spots
column3: UCLA and the surrounding area of Westwood Village is good for walking and dining, or just sitting outdoors enjoying coffee and people-watching. The campus itself is very spread out, and covers a lot of area. I'd suggest walking in from Westwood Village entrance at LeConte and Westwood Blvd. Visiting the main buildings that probably look familiar from films, would be Royce Hall, a tall brick building with two "towers" on each side of the entrance. There's the Arthur Ashe tennis center, and Pauley Pavilion, home of the Nell and John Wooden basketball court, named for the legendary basketball coach and author, and his wifeThere are a number of interesting fountains on campus, when they are running, which could depend on the time of year. (They are operated by recycling the water.)In "The Village", area is full of first-run film theaters that have been there for years, possibly a few since the 1930s. If there's a "premiere" of a film going on, be mindful that traffic by the theaters could be totally snarled.For a quick made-to-order California "classic", visit the large In-n-Out Burger on the corner of LeConte and Gayley. Their shakes, although very rich, are "legendary" if you ask anyone, but I know I couldn't eat a burger and fries AND a shake. Skip the fries, and pig-out!There is a major drawback to Westwood Village, and that is the parking situation. The LAPD had been cracking-down on "phony" valet parking signs in front of many of the spots on the street. That said, with a little patience, you can find a street spot, but be careful to see how long parking is permitted, as they will ticket you! For peace of mind, I'd say spring for a spot in a car park, as they're many around.

column2: UCLA is knowledge on the foothills,
column3: Once a parent, always a parent, and it was my pleasure to help my daughter relocated from AustinTX-USA to Culver CityCA-USA; she had been accepted to grad school at UCLA. The transition went smoothly, especially since her significant other was able to direct us to secure parking--3 meters wide. We were also fortunate in that he had been here for a few months, procuring their apartment while he continued his career. They are both digital natives, which was extremely important as yours truly is quite behind the times--give me a hard-copy map anytime. But, I was there only to help and enjoy quality time with them, so she used her smart phone to google map our route to pedal to the renowned UCLA campus. But it wasn't so simple; we first needed to go to a UPS station on Jefferson Boulevard for notarized documents, then make our way to the campus and building where she'll thrive for the next two years. Initially, her google map was fine, routing us along lightly trafficked roads and a non-motorized trail. However, once our direction was toward the campus, not only was extremely heavily motorized Westwood the primary road, but the terrain had gone from the relatively flat of Culver City-Venice into the foothills of the Santa Monica Mountains. Despite my over 40 years/100,000miles/160,000kms bicycling experience, I was somewhat disturbed that google maps would recommend this route (not the first time I've been disappointed with it), and spent much time pedaling in the lane and using my whistle extensively. Fortunately, this congested road did have bike route signs, sharrows and motor vehicle operators who are aware of non-motor vehicle operators. (California, particularly the Knickerbikers of San Diego County, was a dynamic leader of alternative vehicle use--bicycles--when I was homeported at 32nd Street Naval Station in the late '70s.) We finally arrived on the UCLA campus, turning and twisting on roads through it, stopping at the school of public health.I asked that we take a different route back to Culver City, which google maps showed--and still took us the wrong way. So we used our gut instinct, which was primarily downhill--very nice! I did notice that this was a bike-friendly campus, with roads shared between all traffic: motor, pedestrian, bicycle, skaters. And, of course, it is a beautiful, architecturally significant buildings, lots of green spaces, and very student friendly. I'll give it my "Wheel of Approval"!

column3: OK, it's a functioning college campus with all of the associated student activity you should expect. However, what a great place to visit. If you have the opportunity to visit with a potential student do not hesitate. As with all famous places there is history to behold here as well as a very pleasant, albeit busy, campus. Parking is not impossible but it is not easy - we never did find the official visitor parking ( check on-line for a map ). column2: Superior University and Better Location than USC :-)
column3: I loved going to this university. First Class all the way. Beautiful campus and highly regarded education.

Walking around the campus is a botanical adventure in and of itself, but there is actually a botanical garden worth checking out along with a sculpture garden. You will get a bit of a work out climbing either stairs or hills, but this offers different perspectives of the campus and scenic peek-a-boo views of the surrounding areas. The architecture on North Campus is incredible and should not be missed if you are touring the campus. Famous landmarks include Royce Hall and Powell Library--both of which have been featured in many films--along with the cascading staircase between them.

It's a huge campus, very well taken care of. I'm hoping it will encourage my daughter to do well in high school so she can attend college in the future.

We toured this campus as part of a college campus tour (my junior would love to attend here!). The campus has great architecture and really beautiful surroundings. I wish I could attend school here! Even if you are not college touring, I think if you are visiting Los Angeles its worth stopping and walking around this campus.

column2: A Top University with beautiful scenery!
column3: First of all, I might be a little biased as I graduated from UCLA and am a Bruin for life! Sadly, the school has gotten almost impossible to get into, even for top students. After saying that, if you want somewhere to walk around to view different architecture, a wonderful hospital, an incredible, famous basketball arena (try to get tickets for a game during basketball season), one of the best student stores in the country and decent food...this is the place to go visit!.there are many walking tours to see various parts of the school. Royce Hall, the inverted fountain, the law school, Bunche Hall, and I can keep on going. If you are a sports fan (especially collegiate basketball) you have to take time to see the UCLA Athletic Hall of Fame. See uniforms, trophies and John Wooden's den!As far as hopping, the UCLA student store, especially Bear Wear is one of the top college student stores in the country. Bring home a t-shirt, hat or even stuffed animal...I always over due it when I'm also in the store. Also a marvelous book store (other then text books) and if you're interested in computers, Clinique make-up or gifts...this is your place!Bear Wear is located in Ackerman Union, also home to a large food court and a Wolfgang Puck restaurant. Go spend the afternoon, shop and have dinner and end your evening watching a wonderful sporting event!!!

column2: Great Architecture at one of World's Leading Universities
column3: Great architecture. Visitors should especially visit the oldest part of campus, the quad around Royce Hall and the College Library, built in the 1920s and inspired by the Basilica of Sant'Ambrogia in Milan, Italy. The inside of Powell Library is quite spectacular for architecture buffs.

UCLA is a beautiful campus next to Westwood village and Bel Air. Always something going on. Upper campus next to Royce Hall especially nice on the weekends. The Athletic center has every award imaginable displayed for the plethora of sports UCLA athletes participate in. You name it they try to do it. Drive through Bel Air for the rubber necking at homes. column2: Number One University for Entrance Applications

A great place to meander about and enjoy the grassy quads and the intent students as they scurry about concentrating on their phones.
Walking around UCLA and taking in the beautiful buildings is a treat. For the basketball lovers, make it a point to stop and see Pauly Pavillion. Plenty of restaurants near by if you get hungry.

Just go and hang out. Go on an afternoon. The sculpture garden, in spite of the fact of mid-luster sculptures, has an aura to it that surpasses its surroundings. The Powell Library is a work of art in itself, especially the magnificent ceiling.

Attended some time back at Extenstion CenterGood decor, close to dining in Westwood area due south of Main campus.Nice layout, huge & yet cramped, near 405 Frwy due West of campus.Costly to attend for students.Good drive time from home to campus if commutting to campus.

column2: The school still let's you know you're in Hollywoos
column3: Some what of a little city within itself, with restaurants, movie theater and well kept campus to stroll around. It's the University known for it's next generation of Hollywood filmmakers.

column2: Beautiful View, Old Buildings, Open to public.

column2: Thoughts and Tips from an Alumnus!
column3: Can't believe I am writing a review about my alma mater! Went here during Vietnam War, so not only got a graduate education but a life education! Don't know why they say it is on Sunset, because most of us students came onto the campus from the other side, past Pauly Pavilion (guess it is now Wooden Center, and for good reason, but - sorry - I still call it Pauly out of habit) and the Commons. The walk from Reagan Hospital past Pauly Pavilion, the student Services Building (we called it the Commons), and up the Janss Steps to the Dickson Court is the quintessential UCLA you see on TV and in the movies. Atop the steps you see the Undergrad Powell Library on your right, and Royce Hall on your left. From this iconic walk you then need to specialise, and for that you need a good map. Very hard to find a decent map of the entire main campus online! Where you go depends upon where you attended, or where you want to attend. And while you are at it, research where to park as well. Parking for visitors is not a significant problem, but to avoid a long walk from your parking space to your intended destination, you need to check things out carefully. Now, back to The top of Janss steps with the library on your right and Royce on your left. Before going deeper into campus, turn around and take in the view, with Pauly below, Wilson Plaza, Drake Field, and the housing blocks just beyond. Nice vista! Ok, now turn around again. Here is the overall layout - in general arts and humanities to your left, sciences to your right, administration straight ahead. For me and my memories, the direction is all to the left, up to Bunche Hall, where I attended classes in my professors' offices and in small seminar rooms - once meeting Governor Pat Brown (yes, Jerry's Dad) in an elevator .(shook my hand and said Hi-hawahyah as if it was one word!). And what we called the GRE next door - the Graduate Research Library, now called the Charles Young Research Library (very fancy indeed). Fine memories of daydreaming out of the windows of Bunche Hall during classes and out from my own 'private desk' at the back of the GRE overlooking the sculpture garden. Lunches with friends near Campbell Hall. Very peaceful, unlike the protests taking place all over the campus with police everywhere and helicopters flying overhead! I persevered, and learned! My Graduate advisor is passed away, and I am now 68! Another world, a past world, a fondly remembered world! It all goes by so quickly my young readers. This is a wonderful campus, and a wonderful experience. And don't forget all the shopping and restaurants lying in wait for you just beyond the south end of campus - in Westwood! Grasp iyour own UCLA experience with all your might! Enjoy!
The campus is beautiful and a great place to hang out and study or just think. You may see Gigi doing just that with an ice tea and a burrito :)

I spent three weeks here on a Summer program, and it's beautiful. The architecture is stunning, the campus is lively, and it's a place for a great day to learn about the universities of the US. I've studied at UCLA, USC, Harvard, and the Sorbonne, and visited many more schools. UCLA beats them all hands down in terms of campus, location, and, in many respects, opportunity. No wonder that more people apply to UCLA than any other school in the U.S. Prospective students: some reviewers make reference to the size of UCLA as if that is a problem. People who complain about being "lost" at UCLA would feel the same way at any big school and no doubt in the real world too. There are way too many things to do at a big school like this to succumb to the "loneliness" excuse. As for any school, applicants should think about what they want to major in and look at schools that have departments which are strong in that discipline. Visitors: stick to the original campus--the rest is attractive but mainly functional.

While the campus is visually appealing and clean-looking (as is the surrounding area of Westwood), it's also too big and diffuse and impersonal, and the classrooms are overcrowded. If you like anonymity, fine, but you're going to be treated as just another Social Security number, just another face in the crowd, a little fish in a giant sea....totally impersonal, no room for individualized identity or attention.

column2: UCLA campus tour for prospective students
column3: We signed up for the UCLA campus tour for prospective students (2 hours) and had a very entertaining and knowledgeable guide (Thanks, Matthew!). We walked the campus on our own a couple of years ago but the tour was much more informative (especially for prospective students) as there was also information about the history of UCLA, students services, student safety, clubs & organizations, campus life from a student perspective, and insights about some of the different classes that are offered to fulfill general education requirements. UCLA is a beautiful campus and although they have a lot a students, the campus did not seem overwhelmingly large. UCLA also offers housing tours, but unfortunately the tour was not availabe the day we went. And although we purchased all day parking, (instead of the 2 hour parking option) we inadvertently parked in a spot that we weren't supposed to (parked on the wrong floor) and was awarded a $58 ticket. All ends well though, we dropped by the department of parking office on our way out and filled out a claim ticket (as recommended by the parking lot attendant). Apparently many of the claims are approved. Note: if you are going on the campus tour, definitely purchase the all day parking since you will have to leave the tour early if you only purchase the 2 hour parking....especially if you would also like to have to time to eat/snack on campus or visit the student store.

column2: Ucla outstanding university and many events to attend

Other than that, this uni as the 25th best uni in the world is REALLY NOT the best at all. Cambridge, MIT, Oxford, and QMUL are a LOT BETTER. Alumni from 2008-2010.
I was there with my volleyball team. Very nice school, very nice campus. ( beautiful brick buildings)

My husband is an alum and wanted to show our kids where he went to school -- it's a beautiful campus, and so iconic. We even saw something being filmed in Royce Hall (with a new name for whatever show was being filmed). We dropped quite a bit at the store too! Don't be fooled that there is any free visitor parking though...we were and were treated to a ticket :-(

Walked through the sculpture garden, visited the Fowler museum [always something interesting], then through the campus to Westwood. Beautiful campus. Size and topography make a walk-around a good workout.
What a campus, all of these beautiful brick buildings...and thousands of kids everywhere. The lawns are way too lush for a drought.

column2: Lots of neat things going on
column3: Gigantic place, lots of neat events (Book Fair); sculpture garden, UCLA Book Store; Westwood interesting

column2: a large campus in a good location
column3: I studied there and I have been back a few times. It is very well located, between Westwood and Sunset Boulevard.The university very crowded and lively. It is nice to walk around the vast campus.
Love walking around this campus. There are several venues to take advantage of - lots of art shows, musical events, plays, seminars, etc. Get connected!

Most university campuses strike me as interesting places to wander. Students playing games or sitting under a tree contemplating, an environment somehow quite different from the cities that often surround them. UCLA is one of the better ones. Maybe because it's so big, so that when you're on campus, busy Los Angeles seems far away.Well, in a way, it is. This is a huge campus. Unless you have a lot of time on your hands, you probably won't want to walk it all. And while parking is often free or cheap on weekends, especially Sundays, at most universities, you won't get a break here. Forget about the surrounding residential streets - permit parking only. However, there is cheap meter parking along parts of the streets that form the boundary.Be sure to visit the Mathias botanical garden, maybe the Fowler museum and the sculpture garden. All free.
One of the best universities in the US and the world. Amazing campus in the suburb of Los Angeles with lots of things to do in and outside of campus.

If you are a tourist UCLA is a very pretty campus and is a must visit if you are thinking of attending school here! The location is wonderful and easy walking distance to Westwood village a fun place to eat and shop!
Nothing to see.Very difficult to get to the Quad to walk around.Most of the buildings are not worth seeing.
long lines and hot , but worth it to be there, will go again when family got together soon, for birthday or holidays

While in Los Angeles, I had the chance to visit more than once this beautiful campus, in the heart of LA (you are in the Westwood Village, therefore, you can easily get whatever you may need just walking around; moreover iconic neighborhoods as Bel Air and Beverly Hills are not far).To be honest, it is more an universitary city rather than just a campus (there is also an hospital, not to talk of all the sport facilities)It must be an exciting place to study
One of the top universities in the world, the campus is just amazing, with awesome views of Hill. Quiet, clean & a great place to study

I come here at least 3X a month for volunteer work and my doctors are here. The campus and hospital are great. Parking can get expensive and challenging. But so close to Westwood Village - in fact, that's where it is - so you get a plethora of choices for whatever you may need. Shopping, eating, entertainment, movies etc. Fun, youthful, beautiful!
beautiful campus, worth visiting! If you have time also try to see a basketball game, the gymnasium is amazing and the crowd makes you feel all the energy!
and in a great area; westwood. you can drive around some of it, but best to park and walk around. then, go into westwood for a bit to eat and enjoy the best of west LA>

I attended a week long conference here and I just love spending time walking through the campus, looking at the old brick buildings and thinking of all the sports history. Bookstore is pretty awesome too. Nice location to downtown Westwood.

column2: The Perfect Setting for a College
column3: the campus at UCLA is a wonderful place to walk around, 365 days a year. The buildings are spectacular, the campus environment is infectious. What a great place to go to college

There are some sculptures, some grassy areas and a small museum. The student store is well stocked and there are several food options. However, it is a college campus set up for college students so lacks the allure of some other destinations in Los Angeles.

column2: Enjoy the sense of academic there
column3: The campus is good but maybe I have been traveling to lots of places and lots of university campuses. I am not feeling excited and there seems not too big differences compared to the campus of the other universities. I did not find a sign with the words UCLA after asking for some students. Not sure if there is something like that finally.

Everyone has a dream school. For some this is it. If you have kids 12-16 bring them here to an event (sports or art) or just wander around the campus on a sunny day. It may inspire them to work harder in school to get the 4.0 grade average that they say it takes to get admitted here.For an event, check out the events at Royce Hall or try some lesser watched sports like water polo, women's swimming, volleyball or track and field. (Check the UCLA Sports game schedules on line). You could also watch a basketball game in the place where John Wooden, the greatest coach in the history of basketball coached.

column2: A bit biased but fair....a great addition to your itinerary
column3: Yes, I graduated from UCLA, but I consider myself a fair reviewer of attractions...and this campus is not to be missed for those traveling to Los Angeles. I took my wife to show her around this beautiful campus....if you like architecture, you will love it! (Lots of architectural designs). If you like nature, you will love it! (Botanical Gardens are located in the south-east). If you like art, you will love it! (Sculpture Garden is located in the north-east). If you like hollywood showbiz-related places, you will love it! (Hundreds of TV shows, movies and commercials have been shot here). If you like sports, you will love it! (The Morgan Center perfectly showcases all the trophies and history of the most successful university in college sports!). Shall I say more? There is something for everyone at UCLA.
Got lost in Beverly Hills and ended up at UCLA. Oh what a beautiful campus, and the dorms looked very upscale from the outside. The grounds were very clean with so much beautiful buildings.

column2: A great university and a beautiful campus
column3: If you are near westwood UCLA is a place to visit. One of the great universities in The US, the campus is a job to explore. From the Arboretum in the south end to the Sculpture garden in the northwen end this is a great place to explore. When you are done you are 5-10 minutes from the Getty Art museum campus.
The UCLA campus is both hilly and huge, so be sure to hear comfortable shoes. Find the inverted fountain. It's way cool

The campus is huge and surprisingly beautiful. To take a walk here is delightful: Every building is elegant, and students are always energetic. UCLA stores in Akerman Union is convenient for travelers to find souvenir. Also, the restaurants provide choices of fast food.

column2: walk on campus and visit to bookstore
column3: Yes, that's what we did when there. Stopped by one of the theaters on campus: beautiful. Saw the spot where MLK spoke to students back in the 60's. Loved the bookstore and bought a bears tee shirt.

Worth the visit. Is big! You can see all the advances in technology in a classroom. Dont leave without a visit to the store. I got my UCLA originalSoccer t shirt there!! The store have a huge selection on UCLA items for every taste and budget. We enjoyed the visit a lot.

column2: Have a break from the city at a campus
column3: It was lots of fun to see the large campus area and visit the UCLA store at the campus. Eating and sports are cheap even for visitors. Good atmosphere.

A relatively lovely campus in the middle of a big metropolis with a sculpture garden, rolling lawns, some beautiful architecture, wonderful cultural and athletic venues and lively young people everywhere. This is not one of the most beautiful campuses in the states (which include Princeton, Cornell, Yale, U of Virginia etc), or even this state (check out UC Santa Cruz for locale in the redwoods by the ocean and UCSD for location, or UC Berkley for the architecture, USD and USF for views, Stanford for campus). This U.C. campus is BIG. Wear comfortable shoes. There's not surprisingly a lot going on given how many students therev are. And Westwood Village is at its foot.
Location, diversity, education - it doesn't get any better. Very strong undergrad and grad dprograms.

I have visited UCLA a number of times. When I was in high school, our high school honors group took a tour of the campus. My sister also went to UCLA and was in a sorority there; we used to drive from our home town to UCLA several times a year to take her to school and back. As such, I got to know UCLA early on. We also have attended graduation ceremonies at the campus.its a leading university; the one thing I do not like is that the football team does not play at the UCLA campus but way across town in Pasadena at the Rose Bowl. Shuttle buses do take students back and forth so they can go to the game.Its a good university and interesting to visit. The surrounding community around the campus is fun to go to.We recently visited again on our trip to LA.
Great campus with lots of sights to take in... Large campus. Great buildings and the library is worth seeing.. Famous pallet pavillon is awesome and hey this UCLA

When touring the UCLA campus in Westwood, I was most impressed with the fact that one of the world's leading and most highly regarded medical centers is located there: the RONALD REAGAN UCLA MEDICAL CENTER. The Fowler Museum, with its impressive art exhibitions, is also located there. Upon entry, be sure to get a map to guide you to the various buildings and points of interest because not only is the campus beautiful, it is large and expansive, but well worth the trip.

I was recently working on campus during move-ins and the campus is full of life. Maybe because everyone was excited to start the new school year, lol. The students were very helpful! There was a lot of traffic in and out, but that's expected during that time. The setting of the campus is very nice with an easy layout. column2: Worth walking around if you have time.

Visit UCLA for a walk-around or go see a performance. It's a wonderful campus setting and worth a visit.
Toured the film department, walked all over campus. Beautiful place, helpful and friendly people. Enjoyed the scenery and book store, taking advantage of all the school offered.
Learning is for the mind what exercise is for the body.This place is possibly the nicest place one could imagine for stimulating mind and body.Students today will shape tomorrow.

UCLA campus is a real oasis in the hustle and bustle of LA. Located in the suburb of Westwood with Sunset Boulevard on the northern boundary it is an open a spacious campus full of trees and promenades. AMAZING campus and beautiful hills. Very nice buildings and open spaces. Highly recommend to walk or drive through!

I came to UCLA twice during my stay in LA. My friend who is studying here showing me around and I love the place! It's a huge campus to walk around and we had chinese express food at cafeteria. It's nothing that particularly special,but definitely worth visiting. Make sure to take one day trip here when you come visit los angeles.

Back when the earth was still cooling and the dinosaurs were walking the earth I actually attended UCLA. Wow, how things have changed! It is a good place to visit. It is on the way to Beverly Hills so you can easily make a detour for 5-10 mins. Worth stopping by and getting a feel for one of the top schools in the world

A great place to visit even if you are not on a college hunt. The tour is very informative and takes you to many landmarks on this beautiful campus. Chances are it will be sunny when you go which makes everything so much better. Highly recommend.

there are so many cool and historical building in the campus. I wanted to go to acharman union building but kind of hard to find it... so you should check the campus map and plan what you want to see in there! it's huge campus so it's easy to get lost...

Went for a visit and this school did not disappoint. What a awesome campus and the tour guides do a pretty good job of showing of there wonderful school. Totally enjoyed the experience.

Very large campus, almost a little city on its own. Near the city LA. Great buildings and well maintained. Friendly and helpful students. Highly ranked college, although UCLA is a state school. Worth visiting if you consider going to college in CA.

column2: UCLA, One of Two L.A. Campuses Worth A Visit
column3: I will begin by admitting that I am biased, I am a Bruin. If one has the time there are two campuses worth visiting in Los Angeles, UCLA and USC. By far the most beautiful, architecturally, is UCLA. There has been a cross-town rivalry that began way before I was born (I'm 68) and I suspect this rivalry will exist way past my time on this earth.Royce Hall is the architectural centerpiece of UCLA and serves as a concert hall as well as other functions. I have attended jazz concerts by John Coltrane, Miles Davis and Kenny Burrell here. Other significant places on the campus include Pauley Pavilion built by John Wooden after UCLA had won its first two NCAA Basketball Championships and Bunche Hall named after Ralph Bunche who negotiated the treaty that helped to establish Israel,I attended UCLA during the early 60's when Westwood was pretty much dead after 6:00 p.m., so much so that Sears had to move out. Then, Westwood had only two movie theatres. Today, Westwood is bustling, all hours of the day and evening with crowds who come to visit multitudes of restaurants and movie theaters.Notable Bruins include Jackie Robinson, the first African American to play in Major League Baseball (for the Dodgers); Ralph Bunche, U.S. Dept. of State whose accomplishment is already noted; John Wooden who won more NCAA Basketball Championships than any coach in history whose first team went 30-0 with the tallest player being 6'-5"; Walt Hazzard who led Wooden's first Championship team, started "The Wooden Dynasty" and later became UCLA's Coach; Arthur Ashe who rose to the top of the Tennis World and sponsored several humanitarian efforts; and Mayor Tom Bradley who became the first African American Mayor of Los Angeles.UCLA's history in Los Angeles and the world is rich and so is, I must admit, is that of USC which is an older institution. Again, both institutions are worth a visit if you are in Los Angeles. But, in my opinion, UCLA's campus is the more noteworthy, today.

We made a brief stop off the hwy and ended up in Westwood Village, UCLA area. It was a fun area with many eateries, stores and best of all, we found a small farmer's market! I love farmer's markets! fresh produce, goods and music!
They have a beautiful campus, wonderful teaching staff, but they have an awesome amphitheatre. They give excellent concerts and wonderful plays.

A great place to visit, and the campus itself is quite flat and easy to get around.But the less mobile should be careful if they approach the campus from the west side (near Pauly Pavilion and the student store). You have to climb quite a hill.Better to enter from the east side, where the approach will be quite flat. Or, if you do enter via the student store, use the lifts to get up to the top floor. More lifts in the building behind will take you up to the main campus level.Too beautiful and interesting to miss. Don't let the huge slope (Bruin Walk) or the massive Janss Steps on the west side put you off.
Photos do not do it justice. See its beauty for yourself and let it inspire you.

As a tourist I think this campus is worth visiting. The best place is the area near the Royce hall, which provide a magnificent view. However my wife lost a jacket in the campus. She just left it in the campus for half an hour. When we returned the jacket is nowhere to be seen. People in UCLA are too fast in picking up things.
This is a sprawling campus with many interesting old buildings including a world class venue-Royce Hall -lovelyl plantings-a museum-nice for walking
Beautiful area of Los Angeles, and campus is wonderful with all its attractions. Local Westwood Village is a plus!
First time visit to UCLA. Was impressed and like the university very much.

The grounds here are so beautiful and peaceful... Unless there is a demonstration/protest nearby! They keep the grounds very clean. Easy to get to on the city bus system and tons of shopping all around within walking distance in Westwood!

While in LA, my family and I visited several universities for our teenage daughters. One of the universities we liked particularly was UCLA. It was a beautiful campus, with many brick buildings surrounded by trees. We went in late winter so not much was blooming, but it was beautiful nevertheless.
